response.answer_text: All major editing apps are reliable. It is the hardware configuration that can make for a unstable situation and therewith cause unreliable behaviour. You have to have a system that is robust enough for editing. There are many different configurations and parameters to take into account. But video editing has a lot in common with gaming. So a good gaming computer will probably also preform well as an editing computer. Make sure you at least have the minimum required amount of RAM , a fast processor and a GPU that is recommended by the software application. Another important factor is the footage. Which codec is used, some codecs are better for editing then others. Codecs used by the camera for storage are optimised for storage, so as much as possible video can be stored on the camera’s cards. This makes it also ‘heavy’ on your system to play and edit. So often you want to transcode your footage to a editing friendly codec. If you don’t do this it can result in unstable behaviour of your editing application. Then there is the learning curve of the app. Apple’s Final Cut Pro and Adobe Premiere are easier to learn than Avid Media Composer and Davinci Resolve. If you want to edit smaller video’s which are completely finalised on one working station, I’d suggest Final Cut or Premiere. If you work on a production that is a collaboration with many specialists you can use those as well but in my experience production is smoother when you use Avid or Davinci Resolve. But if you are doing such a production you probably wouldn’t be asking this question. I also want to stay out of the whole ‘religious’ debate of which app is best. There are a lot of factors involved when choosing an editing application and if you are starting on a major production I’d suggest consulting a post production specialist to help you make the right decisions. If you are starting out small and want do some editing, ask yourself this: Who can I go to when I need help, are there a lot of PC people in your network, you probably don’t want to buy a Mac and start using Final Cut. Good luck with your project.

And if I want a new font, I just say Add and it takes me to the Adobe Marketplace and I pick up the new font I want (highlighted in orange outline)I like the timeline. I like how the synced selection works. I like the groups you can make. That is really handy when you have a lot of sequences that might be on another video layer you can’t see or don’t want to focus o.I really like the transitions and presets. I do a lot of masks and various color camera presets for my team members and I don’t like making the same adjustment twice.I like the Auto-Save feature except when I am screaming through footage and I lose a project. The PC nature of our shop is easy to teach, share projects, and work together with. One day down the road, I will explore a switch to Mac. But for now, we are PC based. It makes me realize how awesome Premiere is but I just don’t have the time to be good at that App. Premiere was not working the other day so I spent time recreating a project. It wasn’t all that bad. You should think of this choice as being the same as the choice of pencil to do a drawing with… A pencil is a very simple instrument and so is editing software. It’s easy enough to learn to use a pencil (you just pick up the pencil and make marks on paper), but extremely difficult to master (be able to do a work of art). This is the same with video editing software.. the process of assembling an edit is deceptively simple and provided you have basic motor skills you can manage the task. However if you expect the software to be able to improve your editing you’re in for disapointment, the choice of app used is about as consequential to the end result as the choice of pencil is to how good you are at drawing.Provided that it can make a mark on a piece of paper, you would say that a pencil is effective at drawing. It’s the same for video editing software; provided it can put video and audio in a sequence then it is effective at video editing, and that includes the really basic ones like iMovie and Windows Movie Maker (if you googled ‘best video editing apps’ and picked one from the list at random, you wouldn’t go far wrong).The best video-editing apps The choice of pencil type or brand of pencil is entirely down to personal preference and the specific task at hand… there is no overall ‘best’ option, there are only different options. Nobody can make this choice for you, you’ve gotta do what everyone else in the history of ever has done and try them all and see. Personally I use 3–5 video editing apps regularly, depending on the project, there is no best one.The other main factor is price… which can you afford? This might dictate what you’re able to use.And platform.. some only work on certain operating systems and so you might be restricted in that sense as well.The options available are covered in the linked to article, and it also does a good job of summarising the plus points of each one. You will be left with a confusing choice between about 5 to 6 options which are equally powerful and all are very good editing apps. You will probably eventually realise (as I've done) that you can’t just get away with using one pencil for all drawings, you need a range for different purposes and use cases.

Currently my favorite is Premiere Pro. Here’s why I like it: It’s full featured and flexible. Adobe updates the product regularly. It’s widely supported in the parts of the movie and broadcast television industry in which I work. I’ve successfully cut live action features and animated TV series, as well as corporate documentaries and varied personal projects on it. It’s familiar to me. Premiere is based on the same source/record monitor, multitrack timeline metaphors that the original Final Cut Pro, and Avid before it, were based on. There are aspects of other systems that I wish Adobe could bring to Premiere. The new FCP’s ‘Audition’ feature sounds amazing; I’ve often wished for such a thing when editing dialogue. Avid’s Trim function is the best in the industry. It is possible that my long history with Avid and the old FCP makes the new FCP’s innovative interface seem more daunting to me than it might to a newer editor coming in with fewer preconceptions. To each his own. For the time being, I prefer Premiere.

The best one is the one that meets all your needs and most of your wants with the least investment (money, time to learn, etc.). You don’t hint at what your needs or wants are, so nobody can presume to give you good advice on the matter. However, there’s some general rules of thumb: if cost is the only concern, then there are a free options, and since most operating systems come with at least one free video editor (macOS - iMovie, Windows - MovieMaker, Linux - KDEnlive, etc.), you might do well to use those. There are also very widely used commercial products. They are so commonly used that one can assume that they scratch the itch for a large number of people. The two principle ones would be Adobe Premiere Pro (macOS/Windows) and Apple Final Cut Pro X (macOS). If you are editing as part of a large production team, then the most popular is Avid Media Composer (and the suite of programs that go with it), since it goes beyond editing and presents an entire multi-person workflow for video production as one might find in film studio or TV station. Beyond that, there are many other editing tools out there, some specialized, all with various strengths and weaknesses that make them the best for a particular individual’s purposes.

Sorry, but there is no such thing as “the best video editing software”. There is, however, something that is “the best video editing software for you right now”. I teach Premiere Pro and I think it’s pretty great but I can tell you it’s not the best video editing software for everyone. Let me break down the main considerations that you can factor into what will make the best video editing platform for you right now, keeping in mind that the technology is always changing and you can always move to a different platform later. Cost: there are several free options out there (iMovie, Movie Maker, etc.) but most of them have a very limited feature set so if you’re looking for pro-quality features, you’re probably going to want to look elsewhere.* There are low-cost options but most of the ones I’ve seen are also severely limited in many ways when compared to their more expensive counterparts. Then there are the big dogs: Avid, Final Cut Pro, and Premiere Pro. These are relatively expensive but they are the pro’s choice.Ease-of-use: perhaps you are less concerned by cost but when you open up an unfamiliar application and it’s not clear where to start you just want to run away and hide. I get students like that all the time. Some video editing software is super user friendly but in many of those cases the feature set is again compromised. So, it’s easy to make generic run-of-the-mill videos. Click, drag, trim, done. No muss, no fuss. In most cases, if you want to get pro features you’re better off taking a course, either in person or online, so you can learn a more feature-rich (and, yes, more intimidating) piece of software.Compatibility: if you’re just making videos on your own for fun and not collaborating with other editors or motion graphics designers the software you use doesn’t matter as much. However, as someone who uses Adobe Creative Cloud applications on a daily basis I can tell you that it makes me so happy to be able to move seamlessly from Premiere Pro into After Effects for animation and effects or into Audition for sound design and sound effects. I can also pull layered Photoshop documents directly into Premiere and animate them or add effects. It’s a huge time saver that all these apps talk to one another. Apple has similar interoperability between Final Cut Pro and Motion and Logic but I have not tried that workflow so I don’t have a basis for comparing ease of use there.Your Commitment to Your Goals: What kind of videos do you want to make? Whatever platform you choose to start on you can expect to spend many many many hours honing your craft. I have been editing for over 10 years - first in Sony Vegas, then in Avid Media Composer, then in Final Cut Pro, and now in Premiere Pro - and the learning never stops. I’m constantly learning new shortcuts, tricks, and workflows and the software is always being updated with new tools that I have to learn how to use (or how not to use) and I love it! I’m committed to my craft and work on it every day. I picked an expensive, difficult-to-learn software that is compatible with other software (even non-Adobe software) because I get more features with the platform than I’ll probably ever fully understand how to use and that means I’ll continue learning until I can’t physically edit any more because I am committed to telling great stories with video and helping others do the same.So, get out there and grab a free software and push it to its limits. Once you know the limits you’ll know what to look for in a next software so you can research the options that fit your budget, learn that app and push it to its limits and keep getting better day by day. Happy editing!

Hi Titiana, I’d say there is no “best”. It truly depends on why you’re editing video and where you want to go with it. Is it casual? Is it for social and/or you want to do it easily on your phone? Do you already use Adobe products? Go with Adobe Premiere Rush. It’s kind of the casual consumer level version of Premiere Pro, so it’s much easier to learn, is cheaper and was built with mobile users in mind. Are you interested in developing skills to edit videos on a professional level? If you have a mind to head to television, learn AVID. It is very much still the TV industry standard. Interested in color grading to create different filmic “looks”? Learn Davinci Resolve. Industry color graders are big fans of it, and many films are cut on it. If film is your heart, go with AVID or Resolve. If you have design chops as well as an interest in video, and/or you already use Photoshop, Illustrator, InDesign or After Effects, go with Premiere Pro. It’s already included in Creative Cloud so it isn’t an added cost, and it integrates with After Effects. Increasingly, a lot of design & media production companies use it for this reason. That said, and this is important: At the end of the day, it doesn’t truly matter. Why? A. Industry standards are changing all the time. If you shell out lots of cash for an app and learn it ONLY because it’s the heat right now, you could be unpleasantly surprised to find that by the time you get to your goal job years from now, a totally different app could be the new heat. B. Once you can cut in one, it isn’t hard to learn others. (It can be frustrating if you stick with one for a long time and then have to unlearn ingrained habits, but frustrating isn’t the same thing as hard.) So, you aren’t locked in for life. C. What matters is that you edit video, and do it so much that it isn’t about knowing a particular tool’s work flow, it’s about the craft. Good luck!

Davinci Resolve is also a great application, but it requires a good amount of RAM and a pretty robust processor. For example, my 2009 iMac with an i5 processor would not handle Davinci. Bottom line… find an editing program that suits your needs and your computer’s capabilities. Yes, it will take some time and effort, but you will be happy for the investment. Now if you get frustrated with the process? Go to Adobe and purchase their CC subscription and then get on the net to find some tutorials.

I’ve been a pro TV/Film editor for over 20 years. Without any doubt, FCPX has proven to be the best. As an added bonus, I believe it’s the easiest to learn as well. Why? Apple reimagined how video editing should be done when they set out to write FCPX. Unlike all other editing software, FCPX does not rely on video and audio tracks. Instead, video and sound are “layered” and their connections to each other are the basis of timings. With tracks, every element timing is determined by it’s relationship to the timeline’s timecode. Apple turned a way from this way of imagining editing because it’s simply not relevant any longer. The old way- timecode based- is a function of software companies making what were more-or-less Video Editing Deck emulators. All track (timecode) based software is really just emulating the functionality of how Video Tape Recorders worked. That parody in functionality use to be necessary, because it used to be required to both acquire your video footage from a tape, and to master your finished project back to tape. Apple decided to abandon that way of working, and has been able to make the first stream-of-consciouness capable editing software. In my facility, we consider FCPX a secret weapon. We’re ~ 5x more efficient than a shop that is using Premiere Pro or Avid. This affords us the benefit of making our videos look better, too. Thats because we have more time to really pay attention to the fine details. (Color grading, mixing, etc.)

My favorite editing tool has been the original Lightworks with the dedicated motion controller and software. The newer version remains the thing I prefer to use when I have the choice. The main thing I am doing when editing is selecting and watching stuff. The dedicated analog control gives me a tactile sense so I can slow down and speed up by feel. Feel is what I am doing when I am watching. Also the sound scrub in Lightworks is analog, so I hear waveforms instead of having to look at them. I can split words and music better I feel, using my ears and fingers instead of my eyes. The original Lightworks was infinitely customizable and the current version is still pretty flexible in this regard. I hate the rigid source/record window in most software, which is an artifact of linear video editing. You can only watch one thing at a time, really. So there should really only be the thing you are playing, and whatever edit you are working on. All the tools do the basic things pretty similar, but having analog scrub in audio, and a tactile control panel instead of a keyboard make Lightworks (with the controller- pricey but worth in if this is what you do everyday) a better experience.
